column1: Hello, I plan on going to the Blackhawks game this Wednesday(March 11th). I am from the southern part of the state. How concerned should I be with going to the U.C? I plan on driving all the way to the stadium. Should I think about cancelling the trip because of the coronavirus, or do you all think it will be safe? Thanks
I’d go. I don’t take any disease as a joke, but I’d just follow the same lifestyle precautions that I normally do.
No one can tell you if it's safe. I'd still be going.
I wouldn't go. Why risk it until they have a handle on this thing. I would choose to do something else fun that didn't include a stadium.

This is a personal decision based on your age, general health and risk tolerance. Also, I imagine, whether you have a job with health benefits. Officials are recommending that those over 60 or with chronic health conditions avoid "mass gatherings".

Welcome to TA! This seems to be a fast moving story. In the past week I have been to 4 large events all involving theatre plus saw opening night of the Pixar movie. I honestly didn’t think twice about it. Now just a few days later I am rethinking all my movements. Is it worth it? Don’t think I will be going to any large events if I can help it for a while, but that is me.

I was against the panic three weeks ago. Now I'm not putting myself in the midst of a large crowd. I've begun freezing meals and prepping for 14 days of cabin fever. However, all the rest of the 3 million Chicagolanders will have to self quarantine at the same time. That's not going to happen. We all need to be aware of the consequences of gathering in large crowds.Edited: 12:49 am, March 11, 2020

I see no reason to gather in a large crowd at this point. While some say it is panic many scientists say that staying ahead of this virus will shorten its lifespan. I am all for that.Hockey will be there when Covid19 is gone.B.
